abstract.p: Vice Pres Al Gore's convention speech contained many promises that would cost billions of dollars and others that would cost little or nothing; listing of specific proposals and their costs; photo (M)

block.p: In his speech tonight, Vice President Al Gore made many promises that would cost billions of dollars and many others that would cost little or nothing.

In his speech tonight, Vice President Al Gore made many promises that would cost billions of dollars and many others that would cost little or nothing.
The proposals that would cost taxpayers money included these:
*Universal health insurance for all children by 2004. A plan Mr. Gore offered last year would cost more than $24 billion over five years.

*A doubling of federal spending on medical research. The National Institutes of Health, the government's main sponsor of biomedical research, has a budget of $17.8 billion this year, and Congressional leaders of both parties have vowed to double its budget.
*More education spending to guarantee a qualified teacher in every classroom. The Gore campaign has said Mr. Gore would spend $115 billion more on education over the next decade.

*Elimination of the tax penalty paid by some married couples. A Democratic plan defeated in the House this year and supported by the Clinton administration would cost $95 billion over the next decade.
*Making college tuition tax deductible in most cases. President Clinton has proposed a plan that would cost $31 billion over three years.
*Modifying the estate tax. A Democratic plan rejected by the Senate this year would cost $64 billion over 10 years.
*Medicare coverage of prescription drugs. The latest version of the Clinton administration's proposal would cost $79 billion over five years and $253 billion over 10 years.
*A new retirement plan in addition to current Social Security benefits. One plan proposed by President Clinton would cost $500 billion over 15 years.
These are some of the proposals that would not directly cost the taxpayers money:
*Regulation of managed-care health plans.
*Campaign finance reform.
*Restrictions on marketing tobacco products.
*Increase in the minimum wage.
*Support for affirmative action.
*Renewal of the voting rights act.
*Laws on hate crimes and employment discrimination against homosexuals.
*A constitutional amendment to give victims rights in the justice system.
*Mandatory background checks for gun purchases and safety locks on firearms.
*Free trade tied to to employment rights and environmental protections in other countries.
